The goal of the DETOUR Act is simple: instill a little transparency in what remains a very opaque market and make sure that consumers are able to make more informed choices about how and when to share their personal information.
It would also require informed consent for behavioral experimentation on users and prohibit user design intended to create compulsive usage among children under 13 years of age.

But don‚Äôt take our word for it, @RealCandaceO. Just ask the @AP #FactsMatter 
üëâüèΩhttps://www.apnews.com/e1afa3f19a054540a7c34ca193bdd9ae

The Deceptive Experiences to Online Users Reduction (DETOUR) Act aims to curb dark patterns by prohibiting the largest online platforms (> 100 million monthly active users) from relying on user interfaces that intentionally impair user autonomy, decision-making, or choice.
I think folks have a right to know if social media companies are using them as guinea pigs, and especially if you‚Äôre being emotionally manipulated by an experiment.

For example, it was reported in 2014 that Facebook conducted an experiment involving nearly 700,000 users to study the emotional impact of manipulating information on their News Feeds. https://www.forbes.com/sites/gregorymcneal/2014/06/28/facebook-manipulated-user-news-feeds-to-create-emotional-contagion/#2e10be3139dc

These design tactics, drawn from extensive behavioral psychology research, are frequently used by social media platforms to mislead consumers into agreeing to settings and practices advantageous to the company.

Case in point: privacy settings that push users to ‚Äòagree‚Äô as the default option, while users looking for more privacy-friendly options often must click through a much longer process, detouring through multiple screens.

Some of these #DarkPatterns, like the fake hairs, may just cause some minor inconvenience. But too often, large social media platforms have relied on all sorts of tricks to convince users to hand over their personal data without really understanding what they are consenting to.
This one might take the cake: using fake hairs or smudges to trick people into clicking mobile ads. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D3ucObzWAAM7bAk.png
Using drop-down sections or discolored text to hide information or opt-in checkboxes? Yep, #DarkPatterns. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D3ucAm8W4AciekE.jpg

Can you tell which of these buttons is a legitimate download link and which ones are ads? Your guess is as good as mine. ‚ÄúDisguised Ads‚Äù are another type of dark pattern. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D3ub5KJXkAA3QpB.jpg

Pop-ups like this one that force you to click one of the buttons in order to access the website is another example of a dark pattern. Ditto for ‚Äúconfirshaming‚Äù techniques like this, which guilt users into taking an action like signing up for a company‚Äôs email list. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D3ubxQuW4AE6kQN.png

I don‚Äôt know about you, but I hate it when I go to buy something online, only to see the price jump right as I‚Äôm about to check out. Those hidden costs are another type of dark pattern. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D3ubqb6WkAI_hWl.jpg
Ever run into a bunch of contradictory checkboxes that try to trick you into signing up for someone‚Äôs email list? That‚Äôs a dark pattern. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D3ubfjSWAAA2m1s.png
These techniques range from mildly annoying to deeply insidious. Here are some examples of #DarkPatterns you may have seen online:

You might not have heard of a ‚Äúdark pattern,‚Äù but chances are you‚Äôve seen these annoying, manipulative designs trying to trick you into clicking, buying, or signing up for something you don‚Äôt want. Today I introduced the DETOUR Act with @SenatorFischer to do something about them. http://pbs.twimg.com/tweet_video_thumb/D3ufglpWwAApBef.jpg https://video.twimg.com/tweet_video/D3ufglpWwAApBef.mp4

I joined my Congressional Estuary Caucus Co-Chair @congbillposey in introducing the NEAR Act, which would address the urgent need for research on ocean and coastal acidification in estuaries.

I co-led @RepDerekKilmer's Ocean Acidification Innovation Act, which would address persistent funding gaps in ocean acidification research, encourage collaboration, & spur innovative strategies to mitigate and adapt to changes in ocean chemistry through a prize competition.

I am also proud to be an original cosponsor of @chelliepingree's Coastal Communities Ocean Acidification Act, which would improve our understanding of the socioeconomic effects and vulnerabilities of ocean acidification.

Changes in ocean chemistry endanger shellfish, salmon, and other finfish & threaten the blue economy, including fisheries that depend on the oceans‚Äô resources to support their families, & Tribes with deep cultural and historical connections to diminishing species.
